title: 105_s1358
content: The Act may be cited as the "FAA Research, Engineering, and Development Authorization Act of 1997". Authorization of appropriations is also included in the Act. Section 48102(a) of title 49, United States Code, is amended to allocate $229,673,000 for various aviation projects and activities for fiscal year 1998, including system development, air traffic management technology, communications, navigation, surveillance, weather, and airport technology. For fiscal year 1998, $229,673,000 is allocated for aviation projects and activities, including aircraft safety technology, system security technology, human factors and aviation medicine, environment and energy projects, and innovative/cooperative research. SEC. 3. RESEARCH GRANTS PROGRAM INVOLVING UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS. The Federal Aviation Administration will establish a research grants program involving undergraduate and technical colleges to conduct research on relevant subjects. Grants may be awarded for research projects at these institutions or in collaboration with other FAA-supported research. The Federal Aviation Administration will establish a research grants program for research on future training requirements and regulatory changes for aircraft maintenance and power plant licensees. Criteria for grant proposals and awards will be published within 6 months of the FAA Research, Engineering, and Development Authorization Act of 1997. The principal criteria for awarding grants will be the relevance of proposed research to technical research needs identified by the FAA. The Federal Aviation Administration will establish a research grants program for future training requirements and regulatory changes for aircraft maintenance and power plant licensees. Grants will be awarded based on scientific merit, technical research relevance, and potential for undergraduate student participation through a competitive, merit-based evaluation process. Authorization of appropriations includes $750,000 for the grant program. SEC. 4. LIMITATION ON APPROPRIATIONS. No appropriations authorized for FAA Research, Engineering, and Development without specific authorization by this Act. SEC. 5. NOTICE OF REPROGRAMMING. Any reprogramming actions on authorized funds require notice to Appropriations Committees and relevant transportation committees. SEC. 6. SENSE OF CONGRESS ON THE YEAR 2000 PROBLEM. Congress emphasizes the importance of addressing 2-digit date-related issues in the Federal Aviation Administration's computer systems before the year 2000. They urge immediate assessment of risks and budgeting for Year 2000 compliance, along with developing contingency plans for systems that cannot be corrected in time.
